author: Karl Rock
description:
This street scam is popping up in New Zealand: fake monks approaching people, handing out charms, and pressuring them into donations. Here’s how the scam works and what to watch out for so you don’t get caught.

This scam works by giving you a “free” bracelet to seem friendly. Once you take it, they show a donation sheet and expect around $20. It’s not a real charity! Even without pressure, the whole setup is designed to make you feel obligated. Only donate to registered charities. Stay aware!

#scams #scammers #scam
title: Don’t Fall for This Street Scam!

author: Karl Rock
description:
Scammers are getting bolder in New Zealand, and today I expose one of the most common street scams happening right now in Auckland. If you’ve ever walked through the CBD, Queen Street, or around the Sky Tower, you’ve probably seen this - but most people have no idea it’s a scam until it’s too late.

In this video, I show you exactly how the scam works, how the scammer approaches you, and the psychological tricks they use to make you hand over money.

This scam works by giving you a “free” bracelet to seem friendly. Once you take it, they show a donation sheet and expect around $20. It’s not a real charity! Even without pressure, the whole setup is designed to make you feel obligated. Only donate to registered charities. Stay aware!

🔸 Step 1: The Approach
The scammer dresses as a monk, often wearing robes and beads. They silently hand you a small gold “blessing card” or charm to make you feel obligated.

🔸 Step 2: The Trap
Once you accept it, they show you a donation sheet or booklet
title: Don’t Fall for This Street Scam!
